div.note: “Rolls the Rhine his sullen course, / . . . / Andernachtʼs grey ruins rise” (MS IA; MS IX; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—In his 1836 guidebook to the Continent, John Murray begins his account of the Rhine journey by quoting at length Byronʼs apostrophe to the river in Childe Haroldʼs Pilgrimage, canto 3 (stanzas 46‐51, 59‐60); and he goes on, like Ruskin pairing poem with prose, to quote an effusion of nationalistic pride in the river by the German‐American writer, Francis Lieber (1798‐1872), written originally for the 1829‐33 Encyclopædia Americana (11:15‐17) (Hand‐book for Travellers on the Continent, 213‐14). This nationalistic pride in the Rhine as a “German” river was a comparatively recent cultural development, as was the sentiment surrounding the ruined medieval castles towering on the romantic heights above the Middle Rhine. Until well into the eighteenth century, as Robert R. Taylor explains, the castles evoked in Rhinelanders feelings of rivalrous disunity and oppression rather than a unifying national feeling. For each settlement, the river represented a differently configured boundary and trade artery. Sentiments changed with the development of German Romanticism and taste for the picturesque in the time of Goethe, while a more unified German nationalism accompanied the political realignments defining the German Confederation, which formed after the defeat of Napoleon (Taylor, Castles of the Rhine, 24‐68). In the “Cologne” section, Ruskin announces some of this Rhine sentiment, but he also expresses disappointment in the unpicturesque commercial traffic on the river. In the “Andernacht” section (properly spelled Andernach), he fully positions his unfolding travelogue in the romantic sentiment about the river; its hills, which are formed from volcanic basalt; and its picturesque castle ruins.

“Memorials of the Roman power” (MS IA; MS IX; Poems [1891]; Works [1903])—Murray explains: “This is one of the oldest cities on the Rhine. . . . It was called by the Romans Antoniacum, and originated in one of Drususʼ camps pitched on the spot. Its massive ramparts, watch‐towers, and vaulted portals, still give it an air of sombre antiquity.” (Hand‐book for Travellers on the Continent, 223) Medieval Andernach was, like Cologne, a free imperial city, answerable only to the Holy Roman Emperor, until the empire succumbed to the French Republic.

“There was the huge cathedral, . . . with . . . the remains of its unfinished, but magnificent tower” (MS IX; Works [1903])—Construction of Cologne cathedralʼs south towers had been suspended since the fourteenth century, and was resumed in 1842–80.

“We went on, we past Bonn, and Godesberg, and Drachenfels” (MS IX; Works [1903])—Successive points south on the Rhine journey below Cologne. Drachenfels is one of the Siebengebirge or Seven Hills, which Ruskinʼs narrator sights from Cologne. Here he singles out Drachenfels, because that peak rises closest to the river, and the Ruskinsʼ path took them over it. According to Mary Richardson, the family viewed the ruined fortresses of Godesburg and Burg Drachenfels on 28 May 1833 (Diary of Mary Richardson, 1833, 21-22).

“These are now as they were then, looking up to the broad blue heaven, these are in ruins” (MS IX; Works [1903])—The intended antecedent of the first these appears to be the permanent “crags,” and that of the second to be “towers.” The Romans did not found Andernachʼs landmark round tower, which dates from the fifteenth century. Both John and his cousin Mary sketched the round tower on 29 May 1833, after sleeping the previous night at Andernach (Diary of Mary Richardson, 1833, 22).
